description.en: A thesaurus of the Eblaite language

definition.en: 'Rain' (when occurring with nig₂-mul(-an); Sallaberger, 'Nachrichten' (2003), 620 and n19, suggests reports of rainfall in neighboring territories were brought to the Palace.

example.en: 2 ib₂-IIItug₂ gun₃ / maškim / ik-na-da-ar / maškim / iš₁₁-ru-ut / nig₂-mul / A / in / a-ḫa-za-luki / šu-ba₄-ti, 2 embroidered waistbands, Igna-dar's appointee (and) Išrut's appointee, (for bringing back) the news of the rainfall in Aḫazalu have received (ARET XX 8 = TM.75.G.2512, obv.VI:3-12).

definition.en: 'Upwards; above; in addition to'; See VE 782 AN.ŠE₃ / a-i-num₂, ʿalīnum 'upwards' (Akk. elēnum).
A kind of long garment, probably a tunic.

Cloak; robe; Pasquali, 'Terminologia semitica' (1997), 219–20, suggests an etymology related to the root √ḥtl, 'to wrap'. The number which follows the term might indicate that it was ‘single’ (-I) or ‘folded’ (-II), although a meaning related to the weaving technique (such as tabby or twill) is also a possible explanation. Other translations include: 'un capo di vestiario', Biga and Milano, ARET IV (1984), 284; 'mantello', Archi and Biga, ARET III (1982), 338; Archi, ARET I (1985), 275; Archi, ARET VII (1988), 204; Lahlouh and Catagnoti, ARET XII (2006), 512); 'ʾà.-fabric with single/double weft', Mander, MEE 10 (1990), passim); 'stoffe-ʾA. a filo singolo/doppio filo', D’Agostino, MEE 7 (1996), passim; 'tessile di medio/alta qualità', Pomponio, ARET XV/2 (2013), 405); 'cloak', Archi, ARET XX (2018), 268); 'ein Gewand', Samir, ARET XIX (2019), 221.

example.en: 5 ʾa₃-da-umtug₂-II 5 gu-dul₃tug₂ 10 la₂-2 aktumtug₂ 2 sal-tug₂ 5 ib₃-IIItug₂ sa₆ gun₃ / 5 ib₂-IItug₂ gun₃ / ugula Ib-al₆ki / 5 ʾa₃-da-umtug₂tug₂ 10 aktumtug₂ 5 ib₂-IItug₂ sa₆ gun₃ 5 ib₂-IItug₂ gun₃ / Ma-nu-wa-atki 5 double cloaks, 5 low-quality cloaks, 8 skirts, 2 fine cloths, 5 embroidered waistbands of good quality, 5 embroidered waistbands, (for) the overseers of Ib’al; 5 double cloaks, 5 low-quality cloaks, 10 skirts, 5 embroidered waistbands of good quality, 5 embroidered waistbands, (for the people) of Manuwat ARET XX 8 = 75.2512, obv.XI:1-5.

definition.en: (Some kind of precious apparel); see Waetzoldt, MEE 12 (2001), 325, who tentatively translates 'pendant in the shape of a mountain goat'. Paquali, 'Lessico' (2005), connects it to √ḥrm, 'to cover'; Archi, 'Jewels' (2002), 187, translates 'pettorale'.
'Selected; of high quality (referred to wool)'; Pasquali, 'Terminologia semitica dei tessili' (1997).
'Opening ceremony', from √ptḥ (Sum. giš-gal₂-taka₄). See Pasquali, ‘Éblaïte bí-da-'à-tum’ (2016).
'(A kind of bird of prey)', see Hajouz, 'Wortschatz' (2018), 91-92. See also VE 1370' buru₄mušen / la-ḫa-bu₃.
'Linen'; may refer to both fabric and linen plant/seed. Also wr. ▶︎ gada<sup>tug₂</sup>. TM.75.G.10142 has the unique spelling ▶︎ GIB₃.GARIG.TUR, see Marchesi, 'Plants and Trees' (2013), 276.
'Linen robe or fabric'; ▶︎ gada may refer to both fabric and linen plant/seed, but the presence of the determinative suggests gada<sup>tug₂</sup> refers specifically to a linen robe or fabric.
'Linen'; may refer to both fabric and linen plant/seed. Wr. ▶︎ gada or ▶︎ gada<sup>tug₂</sup>. TM.75.G.10142 has the unique spelling ▶︎ GIB₃.GARIG.TUR, see Marchesi, 'Plants and Trees' (2013), 276.
'Long garment', see VE 859 gid₂tug₂ / gu-da-num₂, maybe related to √qtn, 'to be thin'.
'Anklet?'; See VE 362 giš-DU / pa₂!(IGI)-a-tu, /paʿamtu/, “foot”. See Pasquali, Lessico (2005), 35 with bibliography.

KUBĀRUM, measure for arids; the origin of term, which is transliterated as gu₂-bar, gu₂-bar, or GU₂-BAR depending on the interpretation, is still debated. Marchesi ('Plants and Trees' [2013], esp. 87n30, with bibliography) reads it an Akkadogram for kubārum «“the large one” (of the measuring vessels).» Known only at Ebla, it was used for the measurement of arids: it corresponds to 120 assammū (AN.ZAM, uncertain capacity). Scholars suggest a value of 0.16, 0.5, 0.6, or 0.85 litres: correspondingly, a kubārum could be of 19.2, 60, 72, or 102 litres.
'(a medicinal plant, probably Acacia)', used to cure cattle; see also VE 291. Wr. ▶︎ <sup>giš</sup>gudu₄, ▶︎ <sup>u₂</sup>gudu₄
'Saffron yellow; orange'; From West. Sem. √wrs, 'plante tinctoriale servant à teindre en jaune rougeâtre'.

example.en: na₄-na₄ ki-sa₂ e₂ en stone for the palace of the king (ARET I 16 = MEE 2 8 = TM.75.G.1278 rev.IV:17-19).

definition.en: '(a shiny stone)'; the term comes from √nmr, “to shine”. The connection with alabaster or the like has been made by Pasquali (Lessico [2005], 72, with previous bibliography), since the term appears as na₄ na-mur-ra-tum in incantation ARET V 5 = 75.2194.
'Decorated'; probably refers to objects decorated with precious stone or gold leaf.
'Scented ointment'; see also Ug. rqḥ, 'perfume, ointmen' (DUL3, s.v., 735).

example.en: 4 KIN siki / nig₂-sa₁₀ ra-gi-i₃ / MA-LIK-TUM / šu-ba₄-ti 4 KIN of wool, price of the scented ointment of the queen, have been delivered (ARET IV 9 = TM.75.G.1286 rev.VI:1-4).
